member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket
member.summary: The DataPacket class handles retrieving information about data packets connected to the current test case.

remarks.para: The methods in DataPacket retrieves the information for the data packets connected to the current test case from the test distribution database. This means that it is not possible to run these methods locally to retrieve information about data packets in the database since they will not be connected to a test case. The preferred method when debugging test methods that utilizes the DataPacket class is to bundle the debugging information in a package that is uploaded to the test distribution data base. When the test case is loaded by the Test Manager it is possible to attach to the process and proceed with normal debugging techniques.
The DataPacket class supports two different methods which are described below.
List is a property which returns a read only collection of all the data packets that are connected to the current test case.
remarks.h5: MatchUnique(string documentNumber, string revision, string description)
remarks.para: The MatchUnique method fetches information about a specific data packet.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement
member.summary: Class that returns information about a specific data packet
member.remarks: The available information is the document number, revision number, description, path, file name and entry point of a specific data packet.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.DocumentNumber
member.summary: The document number or product number of the data packet.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.Revision
member.summary: The document revision or product r-state of the data packet.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.Description
member.summary: The description of the DataPacket.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.Path
member.summary: The local path where the files for the data packet can be found.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.FileName
member.summary: The filename for the data packet.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.DataPacketElement.EntryPoint
member.summary: Compiles a full entry point string for the data packet on proper path format, e.g. "C:\\Folder\\Subfolder\\File.extension" or "C:/Folder/Subfolder/File.extension.
member.remarks: If you want to use this property in combination with the class, remember that the format for printing backslashes differs from regular string formatting, thereby requiring you to substitute the backslashes according to the example below.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.MatchUnique(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Matches a single specific DataPacket of all Datapackets connected to the currently used TestCase.
member.param: The document number or product number of the DataPacket searched for. Leave string empty for wildcard match.
The document revision or product r-state of the DataPacket searched for. Leave string empty for wildcard match.
Substring or complete description of the DataPacket. Leave string empty for wildcard match.
member.returns: DataPacket that matched the supplied search criteria's.

remarks.para: This function is meant to match exatly one DataPacket. If the caller uses search criteria's that make the function match zero or more than one DataPackets, the function will throw an DatapacketException
All the parameter are case sensitive.

The parameter does not have to match the description of the datapacket exactly. As long as the value of the parameter is contained in the description of the data packet it will be counted as a match. The implications of this is that if there are two data packets with the descriptions Datapacket and Datapacket2 respectively both packages will be matched if the parameter is set to Datapacket.

member.exception: Thrown when the information cannot be retrieved from pamel or when the MatchUnique method either matches several data packets or if no data packets at all are matched.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.DataPacket.List
member.summary: Returns a list of each connected to the currently used TestCase.
member.exception: Thrown when the information cannot be retrieved from pamel.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.DataLabel
member.summary: The DataLabel class is handling Data Labels and Station Variables.
member.remarks:
DataLabel
A DataLabel is a like a variable that can hold 0 to n values. When the DataLabel holds more than one value it can be seen as an array of values. Valid types are Integer, Double and String. The value of the DataLabel is stored as an string but since the Get functions returns ValueDate which supports properties for conversion (.AsInteger, .AsDouble and .AsString).
A DataLabel could be stored in four different levels in the Test Criteria file and Testplan file. When using a method like Get() or Exist() to retrieve a DataLabel value, the system will automatically search for the DataLabel in a built in order. The order is described in the list below. It is important to understand that when trying the get a DataLabel value you are not able to get the value from the location you like. It is the built-in mechanism that determines where to retrieve these values.
If you would like to know from which level a DataLabel value is fetched you can First make a call to the DataLabel.Exist(...); method and then check the result in DataLabel.ExistData.Result.
Search order for a DataLabel:
Measurement Point: Measurement Point within the Measurment Group connected to current Run Statement in the testplan
Measurment Group: Global label in the Measurment Group connected to current Run Statement in the thestplan
Global in the Test Criteria (DUT): Global label in the Test Criteria (DUT)
Run Statement in Testplan: Within current Run Statement in the Testplan
When the test execution traverses through the Run Statement then the scoup for the DataLabels are changed in two different ways:
1. The Run Statement in Testplan can hold DataLabels which will be changed
2. A Run Statement is connected to a Measurement Group which can hold DataLabels and Measurment Points with DataLabels. If the Run Statements are connected to different Measurement Groups then the scoup is changed.
For each call to Measurement.Save();, current Measurment Point within current Measure Group is changed. If the following example will retreieve from a measurment point it won't retrieve the same DataLabel value since there is Measurement.Save(1); between which will change the scope for the next Get("MyLabel"); call:
DataLabel.Get("MyLabel");
Measurement.Save(1);
DataLabel.Get("MyLabel");
If you like to save the Measurements in a random order then you could use the mpIndex version of DataLabel.Get("MyLabel",mpIndex); otherwise this strange behaviour will occur:
//since no Measurement.Save() is made then Measurement.MeasIndex is 0
Measurement.Save(1,3);//Save the fourth MP: Value=1, mpIndex=3
// Now Measurement.MeasIndex is 4
DataLabel.Get("MyLabel"); //If Measurement Point five (index==4) has got MyLabel then you will get it
Measurement.Save(1,0);//Save the first MP: Value=1, mpIndex=0
// Now Measurement.MeasIndex is 1
DataLabel.Get("MyLabel"); //If Measurement Point two (index==1) has got MyLabel then you will get it
Station Variable
To be able to use global data in the test environment, a concept of station variables is supported. This implies that a test method can write to such variables while other test methods could read from them. All variables are stored in the file C:\Data\ITP\[version]\Apps\Idefix\Init\variables.ini and if you want to manually add them without using e.g. the format used in the file is of the following:
[SECTION_VARIABLES]
IntegerExample=5
DoubleExample=6.14
StringExample=text
Known bugs / Issues There is a couple of strange behaviours with DataLabel to be aware of.
Two DataLabel's with the same name In TPTool it is possible to create two DataLabel's at the same location with the same name. When trying to retrieve such DataLabel's using the api you will only be able get the first one.
Solution: you should not define two labels with the same name at the same location.
call to Get(), GetArray() or Exist() using mpIndex when mpIndex is out of scope, then a DataLabel will be retrieved anyhow.
When mpIndex is equal to the length of the DataLabel array, the last element will be found incorrectly.
When mpIndex is greater than the length of the DataLabel array, then if the DataLabel exist Global in the Test Criteria (DUT) or in the Run Statement in Testplan these DataLabels will be incorrectly found.
An empty DataLabel is not allowed.
A DataLabel cannot be empty. If all values are deleted from a DataLabel within TPTool, It will still be visible in TPTool (until the project is reopened) but the DataLabel is actually completly removed.
member.exception: A Exception is thrown if the requested DataLabel is not found.
If a DriverNotConnectedException occurs, then there probably is some problems within the txapi_config.xml file.

When mpIndex is out of scope a DataLabel will be retrieved anyhow.
When mpIndex is equal to the length of the DataLabel array, the last element will be retrieved incorrectly.
When mpIndex is greater than the length of the DataLabel array, then if the DataLabel exist Global in the Test Criteria (DUT) or in the Run Statement in Testplan these DataLabels will be incorrectly retrieved.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Dut
member.summary: The Dut class provides runtime information about the DUT.
member.remarks:
The Dut class makes information available about the specific DUT that is under test. It also provides functionality to alter some of the DUT information.
Known bugs / issues Behaviours of the Dut class that are not intuitive are listed here.
DUT position can be -1.
This occurs in single DUT mode when a test method does not have any measurement points. The test method tries to retrive the DUT information from the measure point data but since there is no such data available the default value -1 is returned instead. To resolve this issue a measurement point can be added that saves either the DUT position or some dummy data.
member.exception: A DutException is thrown if a failure occur.

member.remarks: The FlowControl class enables you to implement step support in your Test Methods. When reaching a step point the Step dialog will show which allows the user to Step to next Step point, Continue in normal mode, Repeat the step or stop. member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement
member.summary: The Measurement class is handling measurement data, measurement points and saving of the output log window to a file.
member.remarks:
The Measurement class supports seven diffrent methods with a couple of overloaded method. The different methods is described below:
Get(...) methods
The Get(...) methods retrieve information from a measurment point. It is possible to retrieve the stored measurment value and status on the measurement (If the measurment passed, failed or is not tested yet).
Save(...) methods
The Save(...) methods saves and compares a measurement towards the limits in the test criteria. The MeasIndex is set to next measurement point when a Save(...) is done.
It is possible to verify a measurement without saving the measurement. This is done by setting the parameter "save" to false. This can be useful when doing calibrations. The behaviour to print the measurement in the output tab or not can be set in SSTool and in the TM menu.
Note that only the last measurement value is stored when save to the same measurement point. If you want to store all values measured on one measurement point, use SaveAdd(...)
SaveAdd(...) methods
The SaveAdd(...) methods works like the Save(...) methods. SaveAdd(...)saves and compares a measurement towards the limits in the test criteria. The MeasIndex is set to next MeasurementPoint when a SaveAdd(...) is done.
SaveAdd(...) makes it possible to do more than one measurement towards a measurment point. All measurements are stored in the record file and must be passed for a measurement to become successful.
AddSave(...) has the possibility to attach four attributes to the measurement where you can specify any circumstances for the measurement. These attributes will be stored in the record file. Since you can do the same measurement plenty times you are able to explain the circumstances for each measurement. Could be the current temperature for example. This could be valuable when analysing test results.
It is not possible to verify a measurement without saving the measurement like it is in the Save(...) methods.
SaveMpNote(...) methods
With the SaveMpNote(...) methods it is possible to save a comment/note to a measurement. This information will be stored in the record file. To avoid meaningless text and bad format, all non-printable characters in the comment are filtered so they won't appear in the Record file.
This is an example:
<MP:I> M1_1,FAIL,2,2011-03-04 18:55:04.933
<MPNOTE> "Something went wrong here..."
The Measindex is set to the next measurement point after a SaveMpNote(...) is done. It is not possible to retrieve a stored MpNote using TxApi.
SaveMpNote() without using index or mpId does not have any affect before the first Save(...) is performed or when MeasIndex is equal to 0.
SaveOutput() method
With the SaveOutput() method it is possible to save the text in the output log window to a file.
SaveTestRecordData() method
Using SaveTestRecordData() method it is possible to print additional information to the test record file or to a log file. To write to the test record file a TRD driver must be created that support this. If "DUT (TRD)" is selected in the Debug dialog in TM then a log file is created with this information.
SetComment(...) methods
Similar to SaveMpNote(...). This will attach a comment to a measurement point.
member.exception: A MeasurementException is thrown if a failure occur.
If a DriverNotConnectedException occurs, then there probably is some problems within the txapi_config.xml file.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.Get(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves information from a measurement point, It is possible to retrieve the stored measurment value and status on the measurement (If the measurment passed, failed or is not tested yet).
member.param: Zero-based index of the measurement point to retrieve information from.
member.returns: MeasurementData which holds the measured value of the measurement point and a MeasurementResult with the status: Passed, Failed or NotTested
member.remarks: Retrieves information from the measurement point where the mpIndex is pointing to. You can get the measured value. If no measurement has occured the value will be 0. Use the MeasurementResult to figure out whether the measurement is saved or not.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.Get
member.summary: Retrieves information from a measurement point, It is possible to retrieve the stored measurment value and status on the measurement (If the measurment passed, failed or is not tested yet).
member.returns: MeasurementData which holds the measured value of the measurement point and a MeasurementResult with the status: Passed, Failed or NotTested
member.remarks:
Retrieves information from the previously saved measurement point. Actually the function retrieves information from the measurement point, the built in MeasIndex is pointing to.
You can get the measured value. If no measurement has occured the value will be 0. Use the MeasurementResult to figure out whether the measurement is saved or not.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.Get(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves information from a measurement point, It is possible to retrieve the stored measurment value and status on the measurement (If the measurment passed, failed or is not tested yet).
member.param:
String with the ID name of the MP or the MPG and MP
Syntax:
"MP" Retrieves the information from the Measurement Point connected to current Run item
"MPG:MP" Retrieves the information from the Measurement Point within current Test Plan
member.returns: MeasurementData which holds the measured value of the measurement point and a MeasurementResult with the status: Passed, Failed or NotTested
member.remarks: Retrieves information from the measurement point with string ID equal to mpId. You can get the measured value. If no measurement has occured the value will be 0. Use the MeasurementResult to figure out whether the measurement is saved or not.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveOutput(System.String)
member.summary: Saves the output log window for the current test plan to a file.
member.param: Filename of the file to be saved. The filename could be an relative path, then the file will be saved in the same directory as the test plan resides.
member.remarks:
Known bugs / Issues There has been a previous bug with SaveOutput().
SaveOutput(...) didn't take care of the delay settings in Test Manager In TxApi revision R6D and earlier, SaveOutput(...) didn't take care of the delay setting in Test Manager. The TextOut() didn't print text that was not printed to the log window due to the delay setting in Test Manager. This problem is fixed now.
member.exception: A Idefix.Exceptions.MeasurementException is thrown if it was not possible to create the file.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveTestRecordData(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Saves any arbitrary data to the test record. Note that the Test Record Driver (TRD), must support this in order to get this data out to the test record file. If enabling the TRD log in TM then this data is written to the log file.
member.param: Label for the value to save.

remarks.para: The SaveTestRecordData() method pair a label with a string value and stores this in the test record. The label has nothing to do with any data labels in the test criteria or the test plan, nor has it anything to do with the saved results from measurement points. The test method implementing this function must be connected to at least one measurement point. The log file is created when the test record is saved.

Neither the Pamela TRD driver nor the PamelaNet TRD driver supports writing these values to the test record file. However by selecting "Fault Trace->Debug" and checking DUT (TRD) in Test Manager you can get a printout of the information to C:\Data\ITP\Temp\TestRecord_Dbg_1.csv . This file can easily be opened in Excel.
By using this method a test developer could printout values of interest that would be â€œinvisibleâ€ until you check the DUT (TRD) box in the Test Manager.
It is possible to write your own TRD driver which could send these values to the test record file.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.Save(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Verifies the measured curve values towards the measurement point in the test criteria. The measurement is not saved if the save parameter is false. The measurement point according to the mpId string will be used.
member.param: String with the ID name of the measurement point.
true if the measurement shall be saved in the test record, else false
member.remarks: If the save argument is equal to false then the measurement is verified but not saved (print to output tab is configurable). This can be useful if you like to verify a measurement without saving the result to the record file. The MeasIndex is set to the next measurment point after save using mpId.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveMpNote(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes a comment to a measurement point. This information will be stored in the Record file. The measurement with the name equal the parameter mpId will be used.
member.param: Comment string, which will be stored in the record file.
String specifying the name of the measurement point.
member.remarks:
The comment is saved to the measurement point, pointed out by mpId which is part of the call. The MeasIndex is changed after the call to point at the same measurement point affected by the call. If you directly after this call makes a call to Save(...) without any index parameters then the save will be performed on the next measurement point, but if you call SaveMpNote(string) instead then that save will be on the previous measurement point. This is probably not what you excpect. To avoid this problem please don't mix your code using index and not index.
Only one comment could be saved for each measurement point. To avoid meaningless text and bad format, all non-printable characters in the comment are filtered so they won't appear in the Record file. All previously saved comments for current measurement point is erased during a new SaveMpNote()
member.exception: A MeasurementException is thrown if a failure occur. For example when trying to save a comment to a measurement point which does not exist.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveMpNote(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a comment to a measurement point. This information will be stored in the Record file. The measurement point according to the zero based index will be used.
member.param: Comment string, which will be stored in the record file.
Zero-based index of the measurement point.
member.remarks:
The comment is saved to the measurement point, pointed out by the zero based index which is part of the call. The MeasIndex is changed after the call to point at the same measurement point affected by the call. If you directly after this call makes a call to Save(...) without any index parameters then the save will be performed on the next measurement point, but if you call SaveMpNote(string) instead then that save will be on the previous measurement point. This is probably not what you excpect. To avoid this problem please don't mix your code using index and not index.
Only one comment could be saved for each measurement point. To avoid meaningless text and bad format, all non-printable characters in the comment are filtered so they won't appear in the Record file. All previously saved comments for current measurement point is erased during a new SaveMpNote()
member.exception: A MeasurementException is thrown if a failure occur. For example when trying to save a comment to a measurement point which does not exist.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveMpNote(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a comment to the current measurement point. This information will be stored in the Record file.
member.param: Comment string, which will be stored in the record file.
member.remarks: The comment is saved to the measurement point, pointed out by MeasIndex. The MeasIndex is unchanged after the call to SaveMpNote(string) is performed. Only one comment could be saved for each measurement point. To avoid meaningless text and bad format, all non-printable characters in the comment are filtered so they won't appear in the Record file. All previously saved comments for current measurement point is erased during a new SaveMpNote()
member.exception:
A MeasurementException is thrown if a failure occur. For example when trying to save a comment to a measurement point which does not exist.
However, when saving a comment before any measurement points have been carried out will add it to the first measurement point.
For any other occurence it will apply to the measurement point just carried out.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveAdd(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.String)
member.summary: Saves and verifies the measured curve values towards the measurement point in the test criteria. The measurement is added to a record list for this measurement point. The measurement point according to the mpId string will be used.
member.param: String with the ID name of the measurement point.
member.remarks: The MeasIndex is set to the next measurment point after saveadd using mpId. It is only possible to saveadd to a measurement point connected to current Run item.
member.example:
This example show how to save four measurments. A string, integer, double and a curve. The function is looped using the predefined Datalabel TS_LOOP_COUNT.
private void SaveAddWithMpIdExampleLoopedUsingPreDefinedDatalabel_TS_LOOP_COUNT() { List<double> xValues = new List<double>(); List<double> yValues = new List<double>();
Measurement.SaveAdd(1, "M1_1"); //Save an integer to the first MP
Measurement.SaveAdd(11.1, "M1_3"); //Save an double to the third MP
Measurement.SaveAdd("XYZ123", "M1_4"); //Save an string to the fourth MP
xValues.Add(1); yValues.Add(1); xValues.Add(2); yValues.Add(2); xValues.Add(4); yValues.Add(4); Measurement.SaveAdd(xValues, yValues, "M1_2"); //Save a curve to the second MP }
Output:
This is an example how it will look like in the record file when looping three times.

<CONT> PASS,1,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<CONT> PASS,1,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<MP:C> M1_2,PASS,3,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280

<Y> 1,2,4
<CONT> PASS,3,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<X> 1,2,4
<Y> 1,2,4
<CONT> PASS,3,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<X> 1,2,4
<Y> 1,2,4
<MP:F> M1_3,PASS,11.1,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<CONT> PASS,11.1,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<CONT> PASS,11.1,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<MP:T> M1_4,PASS,XYZ123,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<CONT> PASS,XYZ123,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280
<CONT> PASS,XYZ123,2011-04-29 10:23:22.280

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveAdd(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Saves and verifies the measured curve values towards current measurement point in the test criteria. The measurement is added to a record list for this measurement point.
member.remarks: The measurement point used for the verification is the one pointed out by MeasIndex The MeasIndex is increased by one (pointing to the next measurement point) for each SaveAdd.
member.example:
This example show how to save four measurments. A string, integer, double and a curve. The function is looped using the predefined Datalabel TS_LOOP_COUNT. Each SaveAdd will increase the MeasIndex by one. Each time the testmethod i called by Idefix the MeasIndex is reset to 0.
private void SaveAddExampleLoopedUsingPreDefinedDatalabel_TS_LOOP_COUNT() { List<double> xValues = new List<double>(); List<double> yValues = new List<double>();
Measurement.SaveAdd(1); //Save an integer
xValues.Add(1); yValues.Add(1); xValues.Add(2); yValues.Add(2); xValues.Add(4); yValues.Add(4); Measurement.SaveAdd(xValues, yValues); //Save a curve
Measurement.SaveAdd(11.1); //Save an double
Measurement.SaveAdd("XYZ123"); //Save an string }

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveAdd(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves and verifies the measured integer value towards the measurement point in the test criteria. The measurement is added to a record list for this measurement point. The measurement point according to the zero based index will be used.
member.param: Zero based index of the measurement point.
member.remarks: The MeasIndex is set to the next measurment point after saveadd using an index.
member.example:
This example show how to save four measurments. A string, integer, double and a curve. The function is looped using the predefined Datalabel TS_LOOP_COUNT.
private void SaveAddWithIndexExampleLoopedUsingPreDefinedDatalabel_TS_LOOP_COUNT() { List<double> xValues = new List<double>(); List<double> yValues = new List<double>();
Measurement.SaveAdd(1, 0); //Save an integer to the first MP
Measurement.SaveAdd(11.1, 2); //Save an double to the third MP
Measurement.SaveAdd("XYZ123", 3); //Save an string to the fourth MP
xValues.Add(1); yValues.Add(1); xValues.Add(2); yValues.Add(2); xValues.Add(4); yValues.Add(4); Measurement.SaveAdd(xValues, yValues, 1); //Save a curve to the second MP }

member.example:

Measurement.SaveAdd(1); //Save an integer
xValues.Add(1); yValues.Add(1); xValues.Add(2); yValues.Add(2); xValues.Add(4); yValues.Add(4); Measurement.SaveAdd(xValues, yValues); //Save a curve
Measurement.SaveAdd(11.1); //Save an double
Measurement.SaveAdd("XYZ123"); //Save an string }

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.SaveAdd(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Saves and verifies the measured curve values towards the measurement point in the test criteria. The measurement is added to a record list for this measurement point. The measurement point according to the zero based index will be used.
member.param: Zero based index of the measurement point.
A arbitrary string where you can specify a circumstance for the measurement.
A arbitrary string where you can specify a circumstance for the measurement.
A arbitrary string where you can specify a circumstance for the measurement.
A arbitrary string where you can specify a circumstance for the measurement.
member.remarks: The MeasIndex is set to the next measurment point after saveadd using an index. It is only possible to saveadd to a measurement point connected to current Run item. The four attributes can be used to specify any circumstances for the measurement. These attributes will be stored in the record file. Since you can do the same measurement plenty times you are able to explain the circumstances for each measurement. Could be the current temperature for example. This could be valuable when analysing test results.
member.exception: A MeasurementException is thrown if a failure occur.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.RemainingCount
member.summary: Get the remaining number of measurement points connected to current Run item.
member.remarks: The RemainingCount goes hand in hand with the MeasIndex. When MeasIndex is increased by one, then RemainingCount is decreased by one. It is only possible to retrieve RemainingCount property.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Measurement.MeasIndex
member.summary: Get or Set current measurement point index.
member.remarks: The MeasIndex is used by Measurement methods where no index is part of the argument. The MeasIndex is automatically decreased when Save() is done. It is possible to both retrieve and set the MeasIndex property.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.MultiDut
member.summary: The MultiDut class provides index or name based access to DutItem properties.
member.remarks:
For the list of available properties see the DutHandler.DutItem class.
See
See
The DutHandler.DutItem properties are the MultiDut versions of respective single-dut classes. For more information see the respective single DUT classes.
member.exception: A MultiDutException is thrown if a failure occurs.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.TestCriteria
member.summary: The TestCriteria class is for getting information from the Current Test criteria file.
member.remarks:
The TestCriteria class supports several different properties, for getting the current measurement point, filename, document number, measurement points, etc, from the current criteria file.
Known bugs / Issues Right now DynamicInterval Property and DynamicNumberOfOk Property and MaxRepeat Property don't work.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Threading
member.summary: The Threading class is used to make it possible for a thread to communicate with the Idefix system.
member.remarks:
When you create a thread that should be able to communicate with the Idefix system, the thread has to be registered to the Idefix system either by using or
Use when the thread is intended to live in a test method, e.g. saving measure points or printing to the output tab. Then the kernel know what method to associate the call from the thread with. When the thread is no longer needed, use to release the thread from the Idefix kernel.
It is important that the local thread is finished before exiting the test method. Otherwise you will get an Idefix error.
Use when creating a thread that is inteded to live during several test methods. When the thread is no longer needed, use to release the thread from the Idefix kernel. If the globally registered thread communiactes with the Idefix kernel, the global thread will use resources from the first available test method, if any. When no test method is running, the thread will block on the call to Idefix kernel until there is a test method running that it can use.
It is important that the global thread is finished before exiting the test plan (app domain). Otherwise you will get an Idefix error.
Note: A thread should preferably run as a background thread. When a process is to be stopped with a running thread which is not set to background, then the process will not be possible to stop. this will probably result in a Idefix crash.
myTread.IsBackground = true;
Note: It is possible to save measurements in a local thread but not in a global thread. A global thread doesn't belong to a test method. If you cannot be sure in which order the saves will occur then make sure to use the index version of the save methods.
Note: It is ok to create a thread without register it to Idefix, However then the thread is not able to communicate with Idefix. It is still important that the thread is finished before the test plan (App domain) is unloaded.
Note: If a test method creates a thread and registers it via TxApi, Now if the thread sends any messages to txapi after the testmethod has exited, Then TM.exe will hang when the next test plan is exeuted. Make sure you don't leave any local thread after exiting the test method and all global thread is ended before exiting the test plan.
Known issues The Threading class function has got a known issue at the moment described below.
ITP00846 Measurement.Save() not possible in a thread In ITP versions R9A and earlier it was not possible to use the Measurement.Save() without getting a strange error message. This problem is solved in ITP R9B.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Threading.RegisterToMethod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a thread with the currently running test method.
member.param: Thread-id of the thread to register.
member.remarks: If you create a local thread that shall communicate with Idefix (printing or Saving measurements) then you have to register it to Idefix. The local thread must be finished before the test method is completed. When the thread is finished it must be released from Idefix. If this is not done correctly then you will get error messages in Idefix when the test plan (app domain) is to be unloaded.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Threading.ReleaseFromMethod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Releases a registered thread from its connection to a specific test method.
member.param: Thread-id of the thread to release.
member.remarks: If you create a local thread that shall communicate with Idefix (printing or Saveing measurements) then you have to register it to Idefix. The local thread must be finished before the test method is completed. When the thread is finished it must be released from Idefix. If this is not done correctly then you will get error messages in Idefix when the test plan (app domain) is to be unloaded.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Threading.RegisterGlobal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a thread as a global thread.
member.param: Thread-id of a global thread to register.
member.remarks: If you create a global thread that is intended to live during several test methods and shall communicate with Idefix (printing or Saveing measurements) then you have to register it to Idefix. The global thread must be finished before the entire test plan is completed. When the thread is finished it must be released from Idefix. If this is not done correctly then you will get error messages in Idefix when the test plan (app domain) is to be unloaded.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Threading.ReleaseGlobal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Releases a thread that earlier was registered as a global thread.
member.param: Thread-id of a global thread to release.
member.remarks: If you create a global thread that is intended to live during several test methods and shall communicate with Idefix (printing or Saveing measurements) then you have to register it to Idefix. The global thread must be finished before the entire test plan is completed. When the thread is finished it must be released from Idefix. If this is not done correctly then you will get error messages in Idefix when the test plan (app domain) is to be unloaded.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Timer
member.summary: The interactive timer are used automatically with TxAPI dialogs to count interactive time ( Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.Dialogs). The Timer class provides way to start and stop interactive driver in code.
member.remarks: Timer status are shown on test manager. If Timer is not stopped in Testmethod, it should be stopped manually with Cont button on Test Manager toolbar.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Timer.#ctor
member.summary: Internal constructor, used during load TestPlan. Do not use in code. All methods are static.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Timer.Start
member.summary:
Starts a timer that counts the interactive time. Each loaded test program has its own timer.
Note that the test program enters the Pause state as a result of this call, and it will resume to the Run state as soon as Stop() is called.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.Timer.Stop
member.summary:
Stops the timer that counts the interactive time. Each loaded test program has its own timer.
Note that the test program leaves the Pause state and enters the Run state as a result of this call.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.Output
member.summary: The Output class is handling different output functions used to print text to the Log Window in Test Manager.
member.remarks:
The Output class is handling different output functions used to print text to the Log Window in Test Manager. The text can be printed as information text (normal text in black) or Error messages (bold text in red). It is possible to specify style and colour for individual characters.
Error messages can be shown as messageboxes as well as text in the log window in Test Manager. It is possible to ensure that the message is also written to Windows Event Log. The methods in the Output class uses the composite formatting feature of the .NET Framework to convert the value of an object to its text representation and embed that representation in the string written to the Log Window in Test Manager.
The Test Manager can turn of these outputs in the log window. The output will be truncated when more than 1023 characters are printed. When this happens the output will have three dots "..." in the end of output, and actually there will be only 1020 characters printed before these three dots.
The TextOut(...) methods are only intended for printing text. If you try to print binary data and for example you have a EOF in the middle of the binary string, the rest of that string will not be printed. if you have a binary string that you would like to show for the user, make sure you remove control characters using your own filter functionality before you send the string to TexOut().
Control sequences
Font:
\\f0 Defines Arial font for the following characters. (Arial is default font)
\\f1 Defines Courier font for the following characters
Color:
\\cf0Defines current colour to the default colour that is black
\\cf1Defines black colour for the following characters
\\cf2Defines white colour for the following characters
\\cf3Defines red colour for the following characters
\\cf4Defines green colour for the following characters
\\cf5Defines yellow colour for the following characters
\\cf6Defines blue colour for the following characters
Style:
\\bUse bold style for the subsequent characters.
\\b0Stop using bold style.
\\iUse italic style for the subsequent characters.
\\i0Stop using italic style.
\\ulUse underline style for the subsequent characters.
\\ul0Stop using underline style.
\\strikeUse strike through style for the subsequent characters.
\\strike0Stop using strike through style.
If you want to print a control definition as normal text e.g. â€œ\\iâ€, write â€œ\\\\iâ€. A directory path for example could look like â€œ\\usr\\include\\â€ in a normal string. To print it using this class, write Output.TextOut("\\\\usr\\\\include\\\\"); or Output.TextOut(@"\\usr\\include\\");.
If you like to write quotation mark then you should do like this: Output.TextOut("\"This is a Quote\"");
Composit formatting:
The Output class uses .NET Framework composite formatting feature to create the output string.
Composit Format String
A composite format string and object list are used as arguments of methods that support the composite formatting feature. A composite format string consists of zero or (up to four) runs of fixed text intermixed with one or more format items. The fixed text is any string that you choose, and each format item corresponds to an object or boxed structure in the list. The composite formatting feature returns a new result string where each format item is replaced by the string representation of the corresponding object in the list.
Format Item Syntax
Each format item takes the following form and consists of the following components: {index[,alignment][:formatString]} The matching braces ("{" and "}") are required. The mandatory index component, also called a parameter specifier, is a number starting from 0 that identifies a corresponding item in the list of objects.
more detailed information about Format Strings can be found here:
Standard Numeric Format String
Custom Numeric Format Strings
Standard Date and Time Format Strings
Custom Date and Time Format Strings
Known bugs The TextOut() function has got some known bugs at the moment. Work arounds are described below.
ITP00218 '%' in TextOut string causes Idefix to crash When an single '%' character exists in the formatted string, then Test Manager will crash. If an '%' character is to be printed there should be two % characters in the formatted string:
Output.TextOut("%%");
Output.TextOut("%{0}","%");
This error is fixed in release R7. From release R7 only one % charachters should be enough
ITP00157 %s formatting causes a crash The report includes two problems:
1. %s in a string to textout() will print garabage.
2. A single % character in a string to textout() will make Test Manager to crash.
This error is fixed in release R7. From release R7 %s will not print garbage. Don't try to use %s in string like in printf(). It won't work.
Style formatting sequense need to end with an space character When using any style formatting sequences make sure to end with an space. Otherwise all characters until the first space will be truncated.
Output.TextOut("\\b Do like this");
Output.TextOut("\\b\\i Or like this");
Output.TextOut("\\b\\iThis will be truncated");
member.exception: A FormatException is thrown if a parameter specifier designates an item outside the bounds of the list of objects. Output.TextOut("{1}","This will throw an exception...");
If a DriverNotConnectedException occurs, then there probably is some problems within the txapi_config.xml file.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.Output.TextOutError(System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates an error messages that will be shown in a popup dialog, written to the Log Window in Test Manager and also written to Windows Event Log if this feature is enabled in the MSGD driver in SSTool.
member.param: A number representing the Event ID in Windows Event Log.
A string that will be concatenated with "Idefix TestMethod " and used as the Source in Windows Event Log.
The type of message. Usually texts like "Error" or "Warning". The text will be visible in the title of the error messages dialog.
A string to be written as the error text.
member.example:
This example shows how to use the TextOutError(int, string, string, string) method.
Output.TextOutError(1201, "My Module", "Message Title", "This error messages will be written to Test Manager Log Window, shown as a pop up dialogue with the title Message Title and also stored in Windows Event Log (if enabled). The Event ID will be 1201 and the Source will be Idefix TestMethod My Module");

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem
member.summary: The TabItem class contains information about a user created tab item. It is also possible to manipulate the user tab.
member.remarks:
The TabItem object holds a connection to a Windows Form object. Using this class it is possible to control a tab. It is possible to make a tab visible/invisible, enabled/disabled, maximize/normal sized and also retreive the name of the tab.
Known bugs The TabItem() class has got a known bug at the moment. A Work around is described below.
ITP01027 TabItem.Maximize doesnt work the way you expect. If you would like to maximize a tab using TxApi then you first have to minimize it before you maximize it. Othervise it won't work.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.#ctor(System.String,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates a new TabItem object.
member.param: Name of the tab. This name is shown in the UI.
Handle to the Windows Form object to connect to the tab.
member.remarks: Using the constructor, you are able to create a TabItem object and give it a name that will be seen in the tablist window and connect it to a previously created Windows Form object. By only creating a TabItem object, the tab will not be visible. The TabItem must be added to the UserTab list to be visible.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.Connected
member.summary: Connect and disconnect a user tab (Make it visible or invisible) in the user interface. It is also possible to check the Connected status.
member.remarks: The Connected property is used to make a user tab visible or invisible in the Test Manager user interface. When connecting a tab it is automatically selected. When disconnecting a tab it is removed from the tablist window.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.Name
member.summary: Check the name of a user tab.
member.remarks: The Name property is used to get the name of a user tab. It is only possible to get the name of the tab. It is not possible to change the name.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.Enabled
member.summary: Check or set the enable state for a user tab.
member.remarks: The Enabled property is used to change the enable/disable state and also to check current state. All tabs are enabled by default. When the tab is disabled it is visible but not possible to select for a user.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.Maximized
member.summary: Check or set the Maximize or Normal state of a user tab.
member.remarks: The Maximized property is used to change between maximized and normal mode for a tab and also to check current mode. When the tab is maximized the window inside the tab will be shown on the complete screen. The window will be maximised until Maximise is set to false, or until another tab is selected either by the program or by the operator.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.TabItem.Select
member.summary: Selects and brings the user tab to the foreground.
member.remarks: The Select() method is used to programatically select a tab. The content of the tab window is shown.
member.exception: A TabException occurs, if trying to select a tab which is not connected.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabItem
member.summary: The SystemTabItem makes it possible to manipulate the system tab.
member.remarks: The SystemTabItem class makes it possible to select and disconnect the system tab. It is also possible to retrieve the name of the tab. The SystemTabItem could be one of the following items: Output, Measurement or Statistics.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabItem.Disconnect
member.summary: Disconnects the System Tab.
member.remarks: The Disconnect() method removes the System Tab. It is not possible to reconnect unless the Test Manager is restarted. It is not possible to disconnect the Output tab.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabItem.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the system tab.
member.example:
This example shows how to retrieve the name of a System Tab.
string a = systablist.Output.Name;

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabItem.Select
member.summary: Selects and brings the system tab to the foreground.
member.remarks: The Select() method is used to programatically select a system tab. The content of the tab window is shown.
member.example:
This example show how to Select the Measurement Tab
Tab.SystemTabs.Measurement.Select();
member.exception: A TabException occurs, if trying to select a tab which is not connected.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabList
member.summary: The SystemTabList holds the three SystemTabItems: Output, Measurement and Statistics.
member.remarks: The SystemTabList object is not a real list of objects as the class name makes you believe. It holds three SystemTabItems objects, which makes it possible to select and disconnect the different system tabs. It is not possible to enumerate the list like it is for the user tabs.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabList.Output
member.summary: Gets the Output system tab in the Test Manager.
member.remarks: The Output property makes it possible to select the tab. It is not possible to disconnect the output window.
member.example:
This example show how to select and disconnect the system tabs.
Tab.SystemTabs.Output.Select();

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabList.Measurement
member.summary: Gets the Measurement system tab in the Test Manager.
member.remarks: The Measurement property makes it possible to select and disconnect the tab.
member.example:
This example show how to select the system tab.
Tab.SystemTabs.Measurement.Select();

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.SystemTabList.Statistics
member.summary: Gets the Statistics system tab in the Test Manager.
member.remarks: The Statistics property makes it possible to select and disconnect the tab.
member.example:
This example show how to disconnect the system tab.
Tab.SystemTabs.Measurement.Disconnect();

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Runtime.UserInfo.Dialogs
member.summary:
The class provides ways to display or collect information to or from the user. There's a wide range of different alternatives ready, including dialog windows for information and error messages, user input through input fields, radio buttons and checkboxes as well as Yes/No questions.
It is important to use this class for user dialogs instead of writing your own, first of all because it saves you the trouble of adjusting controls to suite the needs of run time tests using Idefix, but also since otherwise system logging will not be utilized.
When using a dialog in a SPLIT then all threads will be paused while the dialog is shown. If this behaviour is not acceptable then you have to write your own dialog. Beware of the system logging issue described above.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems
member.summary: SupportSystems class enables retrieving product information based on driver settings in PamelaNet.

member.name: F:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.globalID
member.summary: description for globalID variable The globalID is a private static member variable that are used to hold the current dut's ID details cached. Every time the static readonly property CurrentDut is accessed.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.RenewDutIfNeeded
member.summary: description for RenewDutIfNeeded() function RenewDutIfNeeded() makes sure that the private static member variable globalID always reflects the current dut. This function is called everytime an access is made to the static readonly property globalID. If the current dut*s ID number don't match the ID number of globalID, the structure is renewed.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.IdInfo
member.summary: A class used to retrieve all information about an individual based on its ID.
member.remarks:
The IdInfo class makes information available about the specific individual stored in traceability database.
The data source is database configured by Pamela.NET ProductInfo interface. By default there are available BarXml and BarTrack drivers.
Known issues To debug this class in Visual Studio, the command line arguments in project debug properties shall be setup. Values of /testtype and /product must be exists in SteamDB (Steam connection are configured by Pamela.Net) In case of default ITP installation they should be:
/testtype="TxApitestsuite" /product="Test of EXB2B:ROJ 208 367/1:R2A:66" "<Your testplan>" "<Your criteria>" <DutID>
If Product ID number is not found, the TxApiBaseException is thrown.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.IdInfo.GetIdInfo(System.String)
member.summary: GetIdInfo() queries the product traceability system for information of the individual specified by parIdNumber parameter.
member.remarks:
Static method.
The return value contains individual data downloaded from traceability system.
member.param: Input string that specifies the ID for individual to be downloaded.
member.returns: Value contains individual data downloaded from traceability system
member.exception: The connection to traceability system is required.

member.summary: Public constructor for IdInfo. Initialize instance of IdInfo and downloads individual data from traceability system
member.param: ID for individual to be download.
member.exception: The connection to traceability system is required.

member.summary: Gets the IdNumber of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks: ReadOnly property.

member.summary: Gets the ProductNumber of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks: ReadOnly property.

member.summary: Gets the RState of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks: ReadOnly property.

member.summary: Gets the ProductName of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks: ReadOnly property.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.IdInfo.Date
member.summary: Gets the Date that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks:
ReadOnly property.
Date contains manufacturing date of individual.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.IdInfo.Status
member.summary: Gets the Status of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks:
ReadOnly property.
The property value is string with 2 chars. The Status values may be:
CR - CREATED = Start status for individuals that are created locally.
?? - REGISTERED = Start status for external individuals that are registered locally.
RV - REVISED = Individual information has been changed.
?? - STORED = = Individual has been stored.
SH - SHIPPED = Individual has been shipped, that is; left the site. Can be undone within a time limit.
SC - SCRAPPED = Individual information has been changed.
RV - REVISED = Individual has been scrapped. Can be undone within a time limit.
?? - the return value is 2 symbols, however the real value is not clarified.

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.SupportSystems.IdInfo.TestFlag
member.summary: Gets the TestFlag of individual that are downloaded to instance of IdInfo.
member.remarks:
ReadOnly property.
The property value is string with 1 char. The TestFlag values may be:
F for Failed
P for Passed
N for Not tested

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.Com
member.summary: This class lets the user register COM objects without the need of beeing administrator. This is useful in Vista. Many instrument drivers are COM objects. This class is a convenience wrapper around CommandHandler class and uses regsvr32.exe in the background.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.Com.RegisterServer(System.String)
member.summary: Register a com object, the application does not need to be running as admin to use it.
member.param: The name and path of the com object
member.remarks: The user is responsible for protecting the dll path with double quotes when needed.
member.example: Idefix.TxApi.Tools.Com.RegisterServer("\"C:\\2009\\Test 2\\CYA 103 999 PictureViewer.dll\"");

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.Com.UnregisterServer(System.String)
member.summary: Unregister a com object
member.param: The name and path of the com object
member.remarks: The user is responsible for protecting the dll path with double quotes when needed.
member.example: Idefix.TxApi.Tools.Com.UnregisterServer("\"C:\\2009\\Test 2\\CYA 103 999 PictureViewer.dll\"");

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore
member.summary: This class stores objects or values in a global store that can be accessed from any test plan.
member.exception: A GlobalObjectStoreException is thrown if the requested object does not exist.

member.name: T:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.GlobalObject`1
member.summary: This class handles the value or object that is stored in the global store
member.typeparam: The type of the object or value

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.GlobalObject`1.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Use this to get or create an object or value in the global object store
member.param: The identifier of the object or value

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.GlobalObject`1.#ctor(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Use this to create an object in the global object store
member.param: The identifier of the global object
The arguments witch will be used when the global object handler creats the new object

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.GlobalObject`1.Identifier
member.summary: The identifier of the object in use

member.name: P:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.GlobalObject`1.Value
member.summary: The value or object in the global object store

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.List
member.summary: List all objects or values in the global object store
member.returns: A list of all Identifiers in the global object store.
member.remarks: This function returns a list af all objects that currently exists in the global object store. An Idefix internal object 'TxApi_GlobalDomain_NameList' will be listed by this function as well. If using the count property on the result from the List() function then the internal 'TxApi_GlobalDomain_NameList' object will be included. This means that if count returns 1 then you don't have any objects created by you.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.Remove(System.String)
member.summary: Remove an previous created object from the global object store.
member.param: The identifier of the object or value to remove
member.remarks: This function cleans up a specified global object. After this function is executed then you are not able to use that object anylonger. A GlobalObjectStoreException is thrown if you try to remove an not existing object.
member.exception: A GlobalObjectStoreException is thrown if the requested object does not exist.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.Clear
member.summary: Removes all objects or values in the global object store.
member.remarks: This function removes (deletes) all global objects that exists. Make sure all objects are not needed any longer before this method is used.

member.name: M:Idefix.TxApi.Tools.GlobalObjectStore.Exist(System.String)
member.summary: Check if a object exist in the global object store.
member.param: The identifier of the object or value
member.returns: Returns true if the identifier was found in the global object store
member.remarks: It is recommended that you check if a global object exist before you try to use it. Since the global objecta are global any test method are able to delete objects by misstake or it was not created as excpected.

member.name: T:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IDataLabel
member.summary:
Interface contract for accessing data labels. This is used to get/set data labels.
This interface does not represent a single DataLabel, but an interface to access datalabels.
The order of whitch the DataLabel will be searched in is the following:
MP (Measurement Point) in test criteria
MPG (Measurement Point Group) in test criteria
DUT (Device Under Test) in test criteria
TP (Test Plan)
Parent TP (Test Plan) recursivly
Station Data

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IDataLabel.Exist(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check if the given DataLabel exists.
member.param: MP (Measure Point) index to search in.
DUT (Device Under Test) index to search in.
member.returns: At what level the DataLabel exists

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IDataLabel.Get(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Fetch a data label at a given position.
member.param: The element index to fetch. This is for multiple values attached to a data label
MP (Measure Point) index to search in.
DUT (Device Under Test) index to search in.
member.returns: Value of the DataLabel at the given position.

member.summary: Fetch a variable configured for this test station.

member.summary: Fetch a variable configured for this test station or fallback to the given default value.

member.returns: The current number of iterations performed at the given level.

member.returns: The remaining number of iterations left to perform at this level.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IFlowControl.LoopTimeRemaining(System.Int32)

member.name: T:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IThreading
member.summary: Interface for registering threads to communicate with Idefix. All threads that will print or save measuremetns must be registered using this interface.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IThreading.RegisterToMethod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a thread with the currently running test method.
member.remarks: Implementations should allow for a local thread that is registered to run and communicate with Idefix printing and saving measurements during the test method. The thread must be finished and released before the test method is completed or an error will occurr.
member.param: The thread id of the thread to register.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IThreading.ReleaseFromMethod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Release a register thread from the test method.
member.param: The thread id of the thread to release.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IThreading.RegisterGlobal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a thread as a global thread.
member.remarks: Implementations should allow for a thread that is registered to run and communicate with Idefix printing and saving measurements during multiple test methods in a global scope. The thread must be finished and released before the test plan is completed or an error will occurr.
member.param: The thread id of the thread to register.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.IThreading.ReleaseGlobal(System.Int32)
member.summary: Releases a thread that has been registered as a global thread.
member.param: The thread id of the thread to release.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.ITimer.Start
member.summary: Starts a time that counts the interactive time. Each loaded test method has its own timer.
member.remarks: Note that the test method will enter the Pause state as a result of this call. The test method will resume to the Run state once has been called.

member.name: M:Idefix.ITxApi.IRuntime.ITimer.Stop
member.summary: Stops the timer that counts the itneractive time.
